q: What are the main symptoms of a lazy eye?
a: The main symptoms of a lazy eye include shutting one eye or squinting, eyes pointing in different directions, difficulty in following objects, tilting the head when looking at something, tired eyes, headaches, difficulty catching or throwing, tripping or falling over, and excessive blinking.

q: How can you check if a younger child has a lazy eye?
i: You can check a younger child's eyes by covering each eye with your hand, one at a time.
a: If you cover a younger child's good eye and they complain, it could indicate a lazy eye.

q: What problems can older children with a lazy eye experience?
a: Older children with a lazy eye may have difficulties with reading, writing, drawing, and may not be able to see as well with one eye.

q: What happens during an eye test to check for a lazy eye?
a: During an eye test, an optometrist will ask you to look at lights or read letters while different lenses are placed in front of your eyes. Eye drops may be used to see the back of your eye more clearly. If you need glasses, you'll be given a prescription.

q: Who is eligible for free NHS eye tests?
a: Free NHS eye tests are available for children aged under 18, or under 19 and in full-time education, people with diabetes or glaucoma, and people on specific benefits including Universal Credit.

q: What are the treatments for a lazy eye?
a: The treatments for a lazy eye depend on the cause. They may include wearing glasses, using an eye patch over the stronger eye, using eye drops to blur vision, and in some cases, surgery for cataracts, drooping eyelid, or squint.

q: Who is eligible for financial assistance with the cost of glasses or contact lenses?
a: Children aged under 18, or under 19 and in full-time education, as well as individuals on certain benefits including Universal Credit, may be eligible for a voucher to help with the cost of glasses or contact lenses.

q: Are surgeries for lazy eye helpful for improving vision?
a: Surgery for a lazy eye caused by cataracts, drooping eyelid, or squint can improve the alignment of the eyes but does not directly improve vision.

q: How can I find out more about NHS eye tests?
a: You can find more information about NHS eye tests on the NHS website.

q: Can I take a survey to help improve information about eye tests for children?
a: Yes, you can take a survey to help improve information about eye tests for children.

q: How can I check if I have a lazy eye?
a: If you suspect you may have a lazy eye, you can check by covering each eye with your hand, one at a time. Pay attention if you notice any complaints when you cover the good eye.

q: What are the main symptoms of a lazy eye?
a: The main symptoms of a lazy eye include shutting one eye or squinting when looking at things, eyes pointing in different directions (a squint), difficulty following objects or people with your eyes, tilting your head when looking at something, having tired eyes and rubbing them frequently, experiencing headaches, difficulty catching or throwing, tripping or falling over frequently, and blinking excessively.

q: When should I go to an optician regarding a lazy eye?
a: You should go to an optician if you are worried about your or your child's vision or if you have not had an eye test in the past two years.

q: What happens during an eye test to check for a lazy eye?
a: During an eye test to check for a lazy eye, an optometrist will ask you or your child to look at lights or read letters while different lenses are placed in front of the eyes. Eye drops may also be given to see the back of the eye more clearly. If glasses are needed, a prescription will be provided.

q: Are NHS eye tests for children free?
a: Yes, NHS eye tests are free for children under 18, or under 19 and in full-time education. They are also free for individuals with diabetes or glaucoma, as well as for those on certain benefits, including Universal Credit.

q: How is a lazy eye treated?
a: Treatment for a lazy eye depends on the cause. It may include wearing glasses to correct vision, wearing an eye patch over the stronger eye for a few hours a day, or using eye drops to temporarily blur vision in the stronger eye. Surgery may be needed for cataracts, a drooping eyelid, or a squint.

a: Children under 18, or under 19 and in full-time education, as well as individuals on certain benefits, including Universal Credit, are entitled to a voucher to help with the cost of glasses or contact lenses. If you do not have a voucher, you will need to pay for them.

q: What is the age range for ideal treatment of lazy eye?
a: Treatment for a lazy eye should ideally start before the age of 7, when vision is still developing.
